body_content.explanation: a vehicle or device for removing snow from roads or railways:
examples: Hundreds of gritting lorries and snowploughs are on standby.
The track is kept clear by a lorry with a snowplough bolted to its bumper.

body_content.explanation: in skiing, a simple way of turning or stopping in which the points of the skis are turned towards each other:
examples: I just couldn't get the hang of the snowplough and ended up face down in the snow.
Taking to the slopes, she learned how to do a snowplough turn.

body_content.explanation: in skiing, to turn or stop with the points of the skis turned towards each other:
examples: We had practised, endlessly, snowploughing to control our speed.
I was amazed to see my daughter snowploughing her way through a sort of obstacle course.

body_content.explanation: to remove or deal with problems for a child, so they never have to do anything difficult or never fail, and do not learn how to do things for themselves:
examples: By snowploughing all opposition and doing everything for them, they may be robbing their children of confidence and self-reliance.

body_content.explanation: used to refer to a parent who removes or deals with problems for a child, so they never have to do anything difficult or never fail, and do not learn how to do things for themselves:
examples: Having a snowplough parent is not good for a child in the long run.
Snowplough mothers and fathers are criticized for clearing every difficulty from their child’s path.
